newsitem.title: USA: Digital slashes prices on business computers.
newsitem.headline: Digital slashes prices on business computers.

text.p: Digital Equipment Corp. slashed prices Thursday by up to 47 percent on workstations and network computers powered by its Alpha microprocessor in a bid to win customers from competitors.
Digital specifically mentioned rivals Sun Microsystems and Compaq Computer and said it offers the same or better computing power for the same price.

"Our expectation is this will allow us to increase share," said Harry Copperman, vice president of Digital's systems business unit, in an interview. "This price announcement clearly ups the ante for our competitors."

The main customers for the computers, which can cost from a few thousand to hundreds of thousands of dollars, typically are engineers and designers at businesses such as aircraft manufacturers and automakers.
Digital has long boasted a technological edge over its competitors with its fast 64-bit Alpha microprocessor, but has had difficulty transfering that leaderership into sales.

According to Andrew Allison, publisher of the newsletter "Inside the New Computer Industry", revenue from Digital's Alpha computer systems running on the Unix operating system grew by about 50 percent in 1996. But Digital still only accounted for 8.9 percent or about $4.5 billion of the market for chips designed to run high-speed computer workstations.
Now many of Digital's established competitors in that market, including Sun, IBM and Hewlett-Packard Co., have introduced their own 64-bit microprocessors.
In addition, Compaq and systems based on Microsoft Corp.'s Windows NT operating system and Intel Corp.'s chips, together known as "Wintel", have been making headway in the market, analysts said.
"You've seen us for the last two years assert our leadership in terms of performance," Copperman said. "Now you're seeing the company become very aggressive in terms of price leadership."
The AlphaServer price cuts are effective worldwide, while the reductions on prices for Digital's AlphaStations apply in Europe and the United States, the company said.

Among the cuts, the price of Digital's midrange AlphaServer 4000 5/300 system with 512 megabytes of random access memory, or RAM, will drop 47 percent to $31,500. Digital's AlphaServer 8200 5/440 with two gigabytes of memory falls 20 percent to $224,400.
Digital also said it introduced new server configurations that provide as much as four times the memory of current systems at little or no extra cost.
Digital's stock fell $1 to $35.50 on the New York Stock Exchange.
